themes: Exclusion of organizational history in funding rubric
Lack of nuanced understanding of diversity
Marginalization of queer, disabled, and women-focused organizations
Disproportionate funding cuts to certain identity groups
Panelist conflicts of interest and lack of expertise
key_phrases: The newer rubric excludes a history of production as a parameter
complete lack of nuance in understanding diversity
arbitrary decisions from frequently uninformed or personally-conflicted panelists
we were not considered 'diverse' enough to qualify for funding
companies that have historically been very homogeneously white...granted funding
definition of diversity...largely excludes queer and disabled artists, and completely excludes organizations focused on women
city cut arts funding for organizations that were BIPOC by 18-20%, but cut organizations that identified as queer or disabled by 48%
these types of diversity are not valued by the City of Austin
barriers_identified: Exclusion of organizational history in funding criteria
Narrow and shifting definitions of diversity
Panelist conflicts of interest or lack of expertise
Disproportionate funding cuts to queer, disabled, and women-focused organizations
Lack of recognition for organizations with sustained diversity efforts
solutions_proposed: Restore consideration of organizational history/track record in funding rubric
Adopt a more nuanced and inclusive definition of diversity
Ensure panelists are informed and free of conflicts of interest
Value and recognize sustained diversity efforts, not just recent changes
